pageContext.claim: “I could’ve taken a much different stance, I could've gotten involved in [the Mueller probe], I could’ve terminated everything. I could’ve ended everything. I've chosen to stay out of it. But I had the right to, as you know, I had the right if I wanted to to end everything. I could've just said, ‘that’s enough.’ Many people thought that’s what I should do.”
pageContext.analysis: According to government regulations, a special counsel “may be disciplined or removed from office only by the personal action of the Attorney General,” and then, a special counsel can only be fired "for misconduct, dereliction of duty, incapacity, conflict of interest, or for other good cause, including violation of Departmental policies.” In theory, Trump could order the person overseeing Mueller to fire the special counsel, but if that person refused Trump would need to keep going down the chain of command until he found someone who was willing to fulfill that order. Alternatively, he could rescind the regulations governing the special counsel. But either of those moves would likely end up in the courts.
